articles.headline: Giving More Globally, and Less Locally
articles.snippet: Giving to international organizations has fallen even as overall philanthropy has rebounded after the recession. What could make Americans give more to global causes?
articles.abstract: Giving to international organizations has fallen even as overall philanthropy has rebounded after the recession. What could make Americans give more to global causes?
articles.lead_paragraph: There was a lot of good news this week in the annual report on American philanthropy published by the Giving USA Foundation. Overall giving passed its prerecession peak, according to the organization’s calculations. Generosity in nearly every category was up, in some cases strongly.

articles.headline: Matchmaking Season for Republican Presidential Candidates and Economists
articles.snippet: Presidential hopefuls are auditioning economists, seeking policy advice, experience and connections, but most candidates have yet to team up with anyone in particular.
articles.abstract: Presidential hopefuls are auditioning economists, seeking policy advice, experience and connections, but most candidates have yet to team up with anyone in particular.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s the economists’ version of social networking.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Federal Auditor Finds Broad Failures at N.H.T.S.A.
articles.snippet: The agency had weak management and undertrained staff, and it repeatedly missed opportunities to identify the deadly defect at the heart of a large recall of G.M. vehicles.
articles.abstract: The agency had weak management and undertrained staff, and it repeatedly missed opportunities to identify the deadly defect at the heart of a large recall of G.M. vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as evidence poured into the nation’s top auto safety agency pointing to dangerous defects in millions of vehicles, regulators repeatedly failed for years to root out problems and hold carmakers accountable, according to a long-awaited internal audit by the Transportation Department.

articles.headline: Outrage vs. Tradition, Wrapped in a High-Flying Flag of Dixie
articles.snippet: The debate has been renewed on social media and beyond about whether the flag should be displayed, and whether politicians should continue to defend it.
articles.abstract: The debate has been renewed on social media and beyond about whether the flag should be displayed, and whether politicians should continue to defend it.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Stunned by the massacre at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church, South Carolina has been abruptly forced to confront an issue that has bedeviled it for decades: the Confederate battle flag that flies above the grounds of the State House.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Manny Fernandez

articles.headline: Black Church Is Target Again for Deadly Strike at the Heart
articles.snippet: After the Civil War, black churches became what the scholar W. E. B. Du Bois and others have described as the “first social institution fully controlled by black men in America.” And before long, those institutions became targets.
articles.abstract: After the Civil War, black churches became what the scholar W. E. B. Du Bois and others have described as the “first social institution fully controlled by black men in America.” And before long, those institutions became targets.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Atlanta, the former slaves sang their hallelujahs in an abandoned railroad boxcar. In Lincoln County, N.C., they called out to Jesus in a building made of old pine poles. Near Cartersville, Ga., they raised their voices to the heavens from a roofless barrel shop.
articles.byline: By Rachel L. Swarns and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: The People v. the Coal Baron
articles.snippet: Don Blankenship, former chief of Massey Energy, will stand trial over safety violations related to a deadly mine explosion in West Virginia in 2010.
articles.abstract: Don Blankenship, former chief of Massey Energy, will stand trial over safety violations related to a deadly mine explosion in West Virginia in 2010.
articles.lead_paragraph: Don Blankenship always knew exactly what he wanted during the years he ran Massey Energy, once the sixth-largest coal company in the United States. He had specific and emphatic ideas about how to operate mines, how to treat employees and how to deal with regulators. When he issued instructions, he wanted them followed to the letter, and this wasn’t just true about his business.

articles.headline: Gap’s Fashion-Backward Moment
articles.snippet: Sales are slumping at American clothing brands like Gap as foreign fast-fashion upstarts like H&M, Uniqlo and Zara lure away customers.
articles.abstract: Sales are slumping at American clothing brands like Gap as foreign fast-fashion upstarts like H&M, Uniqlo and Zara lure away customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 8:50 on a Wednesday morning, nearly two dozen shoppers hovered in front of H&M’s new global flagship store on the corner of West 34th Street and Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan, eager to get inside as soon as the doors were unlocked at 9.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Hilary Stout

articles.headline: Dylann Roof Photos and a Manifesto Are Posted on Website
articles.snippet: Mr. Roof can be seen posing with weapons, visiting Confederate graves and burning an American flag.
articles.abstract: Mr. Roof can be seen posing with weapons, visiting Confederate graves and burning an American flag.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Dylann Roof spat on and burned the American flag, but waved the Confederate.

articles.headline: A Hectic Day at Charleston Church, and Then a Hellish Visitor
articles.snippet: The visitor arrived around 8 p.m. Wednesday, asking for the minister. It was unusual for a stranger, much less a white one, to come to Bible study, but the pastor welcomed him.
articles.abstract: The visitor arrived around 8 p.m. Wednesday, asking for the minister. It was unusual for a stranger, much less a white one, to come to Bible study, but the pastor welcomed him.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Wednesday was a busy day at the Emanuel A.M.E. Church.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset, John Eligon, Jason Horowitz and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Oh, to Be Young, Millennial, and So Wanted by Marketers
articles.snippet: A marketing frenzy is aimed at those born in the last two decades of the 20th century, but studies show they aren’t so different from the rest of us.
articles.abstract: A marketing frenzy is aimed at those born in the last two decades of the 20th century, but studies show they aren’t so different from the rest of us.
articles.lead_paragraph: The makers of Tic Tacs had a problem on their hands.

articles.headline: Attack Gave Chinese Hackers Privileged Access to U.S. Systems
articles.snippet: Undetected for nearly a year, Chinese intruders executed a sophisticated hack that gave them “administrator privileges” in government networks. Their ultimate target: information on anyone seeking a security clearance.
articles.abstract: Undetected for nearly a year, Chinese intruders executed a sophisticated hack that gave them “administrator privileges” in government networks. Their ultimate target: information on anyone seeking a security clearance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than five years, American intelligence agencies followed several groups of Chinese hackers who were systematically draining information from defense contractors, energy firms and electronics makers, their targets shifting to fit Beijing’s latest economic priorities.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Nicole Perlroth and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Defiant Show of Unity in Charleston Church That Lost 9 to Racist Violence
articles.snippet: A diverse gathering of mourners crowded beneath Emanuel A.M.E. Church’s vaulted barrel roof days after nine black churchgoers were killed in an attack.
articles.abstract: A diverse gathering of mourners crowded beneath Emanuel A.M.E. Church’s vaulted barrel roof days after nine black churchgoers were killed in an attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The Emanuel A.M.E. Church has survived antebellum laws barring black worship, an angry white mob that burned down its original edifice, and the execution of its founder and dozens of others planning a slave revolt.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: Republicans Tread Carefully in Criticism of Confederate Flag
articles.snippet: The challenge for Republicans has been great as they seek to broaden their party’s appeal while also energizing white conservatives.
articles.abstract: The challenge for Republicans has been great as they seek to broaden their party’s appeal while also energizing white conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The massacre of nine African-Americans in a storied Charleston church last week, which thrust the issues of race relations and gun rights into the center of the 2016 presidential campaign, has now added another familiar, divisive question to the emerging contest for the Republican nomination: what to do with the Confederate battle flag that flies on the grounds of the South Carolina Capitol.

articles.headline: Taylor Swift Criticism Spurs Apple to Change Royalties Policy
articles.snippet: Ms. Swift had framed a letter posted to her Tumblr page as an explanation for why she was withholding her latest album, “1989,” from Apple’s new music streaming service.
articles.abstract: Ms. Swift had framed a letter posted to her Tumblr page as an explanation for why she was withholding her latest album, “1989,” from Apple’s new music streaming service.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Taylor Swift speaks, even the most powerful company in the world listens.

articles.headline: As Greece Deadline Looms, European Central Bank Plays Key Role
articles.snippet: The E.C.B. is a lender of last resort, but it has also pushed Greece to the edge of default with its tough stance.
articles.abstract: The E.C.B. is a lender of last resort, but it has also pushed Greece to the edge of default with its tough stance.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As Greece’s standoff with its creditors enters the final stretch, the European Central Bank finds itself in the awkward position of being both the country’s savior and its scold.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: In China, Illegal Drugs Are Sold Online in an Unbridled Market
articles.snippet: Authorities have shown little interest in seriously regulating clandestine labs, turning China into a leading producer and exporter of synthetic drugs.
articles.abstract: Authorities have shown little interest in seriously regulating clandestine labs, turning China into a leading producer and exporter of synthetic drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Ordering illegal drugs from China is as easy as typing on a keyboard.

articles.headline: How SurveyMonkey Is Coping After the Death of Dave Goldberg
articles.snippet: SurveyMonkey’s executives have had to navigate the process of replacing Mr. Goldberg, while running a company on the cusp of significant growth — and managing the emotions of 550 employees.
articles.abstract: SurveyMonkey’s executives have had to navigate the process of replacing Mr. Goldberg, while running a company on the cusp of significant growth — and managing the emotions of 550 employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — On the first day back to work after the death of Dave Goldberg, the chief executive of SurveyMonkey, employees at the Silicon Valley company gathered to mourn.

articles.headline: Cigna Rejects an Overture From Anthem
articles.snippet: Anthem’s $47 billion takeover bid for Cigna comes as companies look to become even bigger to take advantage of the changes in the health insurance market.
articles.abstract: Anthem’s $47 billion takeover bid for Cigna comes as companies look to become even bigger to take advantage of the changes in the health insurance market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world of American health insurance may soon become even smaller, with the biggest companies seeking to become even bigger.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: Justice Anthony Kennedy’s Tolerance Is Seen in His Sacramento Roots
articles.snippet: Justice Kennedy, the onetime altar boy from Sacramento and conservative Republican, has advanced legal equality for gays more than any other American jurist.
articles.abstract: Justice Kennedy, the onetime altar boy from Sacramento and conservative Republican, has advanced legal equality for gays more than any other American jurist.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — In the fall of 1987, a package arrived on the desk of Laurence H. Tribe, a Harvard law professor who had just lost a Supreme Court case on gay rights. It contained the legal opinions of Anthony M. Kennedy, a strait-laced, conservative Republican jurist from Sacramento who hardly seemed sympathetic to that cause.

articles.headline: Health Insurers Brace for Supreme Court Ruling
articles.snippet: About 6.4 million people could lose subsidies if the court decides the Affordable Care Act does not allow them in states without their own insurance marketplaces.
articles.abstract: About 6.4 million people could lose subsidies if the court decides the Affordable Care Act does not allow them in states without their own insurance marketplaces.
articles.lead_paragraph: Their industry already upended with the passage of the federal health care law, insurance companies are facing another upheaval if the Supreme Court rules that millions of Americans are not eligible for subsidies to help defray the cost of their coverage.

articles.headline: Making a Point, Obama Invokes a Painful Slur
articles.snippet: In a podcast interview, President Obama drove home his point that slavery still “casts a long shadow” on American life.
articles.abstract: In a podcast interview, President Obama drove home his point that slavery still “casts a long shadow” on American life.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a single word, just six letters long, but one that has not been spoken by an American president in public for generations.

articles.headline: New Momentum on Paid Leave, in Business and Politics
articles.snippet: As states, cities and corporations introduce measures on sick leave or family leave, even a federal policy is starting to seem less far-fetched.
articles.abstract: As states, cities and corporations introduce measures on sick leave or family leave, even a federal policy is starting to seem less far-fetched.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oregon this month became the fourth state to pass a bill requiring that companies give workers paid sick days to care for themselves or family members.
